node.title: Happiness is being able to afford a surprise vet bill
node.alt: An older golden retriever sits on a wooden deck.
node.description: Money may not be able to buy happiness but recent research shows it helps. But the income needed for a happy life is increasingly out-of-reach for ordinary Australians.
node.content:
["Anna Irwin-Schutze was worried when Dotti, her mother's 12-year-old golden retriever, showed signs of being unwell.", "\"She sort of went mute and we couldn't work out why,\" Anna says.", "They took Dotti from their home in regional Victoria to Melbourne for tests, which revealed the dog needed surgery.", "This was when the emergency fund Anna and her husband maintain came in handy.", "\"The scans alone were $1,200,\" she says.", "\"All up [including the surgery], it ended up being closer to $5,000.\"", "", "
Anna Irwin-Schutze (left) with her mother\u00a0Lorelle Thompson-Pope and her mother's dog Dotti.\u00a0(Supplied)
", "Anna says being able to cover this sort of unexpected expense is why having a high-enough income contributes to happiness \u2014 or at least, reduces stress.", "Her view is backed by recent Australian research.", "Sydney University cognitive scientist Richard Morris is one of three researchers behind\u00a0a study entitled The Increasing Cost of Happiness.", "The study builds upon a 2010 paper by Nobel Prize-winning psychologist Daniel Kahneman.", "Kahneman found that \"in the US, average happiness levels increased with income \u2014 up to a point,\" Dr Morris tells ABC RN's Life Matters.", "According to Kahneman's study, that point was $US75,000 per year. Any rise in income beyond that was not associated with an equivalent rise in happiness.", "\"At the same time, in the US, the median income \u2026 was about $50,000, [so] that point was quite a lot higher than what most Americans were earning,\" Dr Morris says.", "Dr Morris and his fellow researchers found that in Australia, there was also a gap between the median income and the point where increased income no longer made a difference to happiness.", "And that gap is getting wider.", "
Exploring the data
", "For their data, Dr Morris and his co-researchers turned to the Melbourne Institute's long-running Household, Income and Labour Dynamics in Australia (HILDA) survey.", "The survey follows the lives of 17,000 Australians, collecting information on their relationships, work, income, health and education.", "\"They've been collecting data on Australian households for 20 years, since 2001,\" Dr Morris says.", "\"It's a fantastic dataset.\"", "HILDA data from 2001 to 2019 shows a decrease in the happiness of Australians.", "The level at which income no longer affects happiness (the \"change point\") has dramatically increased in those 19 years.", "\"At the early start of the millennium, that change point was about $43,000 [per year], which was much closer to the median income in Australia at the time,\" Dr Morris says.", "\"But in the last 20 years, that change point has increased to $74,000.\"", "The data show that Australia's happiness peaked in 2009\u00a0and has been on the decline since then.", "Wage growth in Australia has slowed in the past decade\u00a0for a variety of reasons and\u00a0the median Australian income has remained at around $50,000 per year.", "\"What we're seeing is stagnating incomes,\" Dr Morris says.", "In 2001, 57 per cent of Australians earned less than the change point. In 2019, that number had grown to 74 per cent.", "\"There's a really small proportion of Australians now who can say that they're financially secure enough that they don't care about their income \u2014 whereas for the vast majority of us, we're still feeling that pressure.\"", "
Happiness vs satisfaction
", "Lisa Williams, a social psychologist at the University of New South Wales, says it's important to distinguish between someone's happiness and their life satisfaction.", "While some people conflate the two, Dr Williams says they are quite different things.", "\"From a research perspective, we talk about happiness as an emotional state that might shift around moment-to-moment or day-to-day,\" Dr Williams says.", "\"Life satisfaction tends to be a bit more stable \u2014 it's the broad sense that your life is fulfilled, that there may not be very much you would change about your life.\"", "", "
Anna Irwin-Schutze used\u00a0her and her husband's emergency fund to pay for Dotti's surgery.\u00a0(Supplied)
", "The HILDA survey measures both happiness and satisfaction, Dr Morris says.", "Respondents are asked to rate how satisfied they are with their lives, on a scale of zero to 10.", "The survey also asks several questions about how the respondent has been feeling over the past month, which Dr Morris's team used to calculate their happiness score.", "The results are quite different.", "\"Life satisfaction for the last 20 years has been stable,\" Dr Morris says, adding that Australians are \"more satisfied than many other countries in the OECD\".", "Income also affects life satisfaction differently to the way it affects happiness.", "\"Life satisfaction continues to increase with income,\" Dr Morris says.", "\"It turns out, when you ask people how satisfied they are with their life, presumably some of them are looking at the dollar value on their payslip and saying, 'Yeah, I'm pretty satisfied'.\"", "For Anna, a writer, and her husband, who works on audio for video games, income isn't always stable.", "Both\u00a0are contract workers and there are times when one of them is between contracts for extended periods.", "The money they save when they are both working serves as a buffer when they have leaner times.", "\"We don't live extravagantly \u2026 but we can afford to pay off our home loan,\" Anna says.", "Nevertheless, she is satisfied. She and her husband can afford the occasional holiday and can cope with occasional extra expenses, such as Dotti's surgery.", "Anna says she has lived on lower incomes in the past and knows how stressful it is to have bills come in that you're unable to pay.", "She's grateful they have been able to put away enough money for an emergency fund.", "\"I'm fully aware that most people can't do that,\" Anna says.", "
Money isn't everything
", "So should we all just be trying to make as much money as we possibly can?", "Not necessarily.", "Dr Morris says that while, on average, Australians who earn $74,000 or more are happier than those who don't, there are still happy people who earn less, and people who earn more but are unhappy.", "\"Even if you earn less, you can still be happy because you spend time with friends, or you have a good family life, or you're pleased with your job and things like that,\" he says.", "\"Those things will still impact your happiness.\"", "Dr Williams says research shows an individual's well-being is also dependent on them finding meaning in life.", "\"You need more than just those instantaneous moments of happiness and you need more than just a sense of satisfaction,\" she says.", "\"Having a sense of contribution to the community, having a sense that your activities impact others\u00a0turns out to be pretty important.\"", "Dr Williams says research suggests that pursuing happiness and personal satisfaction at the expense of other people is \"not really an ideal way of being\".", "But spending money on other people, volunteering and maintaining social connections can contribute to a person having meaning and purpose.", "And those who have this, Dr Williams says, also tend to experience more happiness.", "\"It suggests one way we can go about achieving happiness is actually not to pursue happiness itself, but rather to pursue activities that give us meaning and purpose.\""]
